sen.j: 堀河康胤（ほりかわ やすたね、天正20年9月9日 (旧暦)（1592年10月14日） - 寛文13年1月27日 (旧暦)（1673年3月15日））は、江戸時代前期の公卿・堀河家の祖。
sen.e: Yasutane HORIKAWA (October 14, 1592 - March 15, 1673) was the Kugyo (high court noble) during the early Edo period and the originator of the Horikawa family.

sen.j: 後陽成天皇（107代）から霊元天皇（112代）までの六帝の長きにわたり朝廷に出仕し、従二位権中納言まで昇った。
sen.e: He served for the Imperial Court for the six emperors from the time of to; he was promoted to Junii Chunagon (Junior Second Rank vice-councilor of state).

He served six generations of emperors from Emperor Goyozei (the 107th) to Emperor Reigen (the 112th), and he was promoted to Junii Gon Chunagon (Junior Second Rank, provisional vice-councilor of state).

sen.e: His children were Nobuchika HORIKAWA, Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards), Noriyasu HORIKAWA, Sangi (councillor), and Nobuchika HIGUCGHI.

sen.j: 祖父の高倉永家から分かれた父の水無瀬親具からさらに分かれて堀河家を起こした。
sen.e: He became the originator of the Horikawa family, Chikatomo MINASE, separated from his father, Chikatomo's family, Minase family, which was another branch family of Yasutane's grandfather, Nagaie's family, Takakura clan.
He became the originator of the Horikawa family, separated from the family of his father, Chikatomo MINASE, who had been separated from the family of his grandfather, Nagaie TAKAKURA.

sen.j: 寛永7年（1630年）に従三位となり、公卿に列した。
sen.e: In 1630, he became Jusani (Junior Third Rank) and ranked with Kugyo (the top court officials).

sen.j: その後も左衛門督・参議・踏歌節会外弁を経て、寛文3年（1663年）権中納言に就任したが、同年に辞職して出家した。
sen.e: After that, he served as Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards), Sangi (councillor), and oka no sechie Geben (a kugyo who supervised many matters outside Jomei Gate at Toka no sechie (Imperial Court Ceremony)) and.assumed the position of Chunagon (Middle Counselor) in 1663 and became a priest in the same year.

After that, he served as Saemon no kami (captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards), Sangi (councillor), and oka no sechie Geben (a kugyo who supervised many matters outside Jomei Gate at Toka no sechie [Imperial Court Ceremony]), and in 1663, he assumed the position of Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state), but he resigned from his position and became a priest in the same year.
